title: Does AI Really Make Coders Faster?
description: Slashdot discussion examining recent studies on AI coding tools and their actual impact on developer productivity. Questions whether speed gains translate to better code quality.
author: Slashdot Community

title: 2025 LLM Year in Review: Six Paradigm Changes
description: Andrej Karpathy's comprehensive analysis of major LLM paradigm shifts in 2025: 1) RLVR replacing RLHF, 2) Ghosts vs Animals intelligence model, 3) Cursor revealing new LLM app layer, 4) Claude Code as local AI agent paradigm, 5) Vibe coding empowering non-programmers, 6) Nano banana pointing to LLM GUI future.
author: Andrej Karpathy

title: AI Tools Make Coders More Important, Not Less
description: Harvard Business Review analysis by Michael Li argues AI coding tools increase the value of experienced engineers. Details three rules for 'vibe coding era': 1) Double-check every change with automated tests and human review, 2) Limit AI access to safe 'practice' environments, never live customer data, 3) Keep experienced engineers in charge of design, rules, and safety checks.
author: Michael Li

title: Reflections on AI at the End of 2025
description: Hacker News discussion highlighting key AI developments in 2025. Notable points: Programmers' resistance to AI-assisted programming has lowered considerably, with increased acceptance of tools. Discussion explores how 'vibe coding' will terraform software development and alter job descriptions in the coming year.
author: Hacker News Community

title: Your job is to deliver code you have proven to work
description: Simon Willison addresses AI-assistance in software development and emphasizes the importance of delivering proven, working code. Discusses validation practices when using LLMs for development.
author: Simon Willison

title: AI Coding Tools in 2025: Welcome to the Agentic CLI Era
description: The New Stack explores how AI coding tools are evolving toward agentic CLI interfaces. Discusses the shift from simple code completion to autonomous coding agents.
author: The New Stack

title: The State of AI Coding Report 2025
description: Hacker News discussion on comprehensive AI coding report. Key finding: lines of code per developer grew from 4,450 to 7,839 as AI tools act as force multipliers. AI code review agent used by 2,000 companies including PostHog, Brex, and Fortune 500 firms.
author: Hacker News Community

title: AI coding is now everywhere. But not everyone is convinced.
description: MIT Technology Review explores the rise of AI coding tools and developer skepticism. Examines adoption rates, effectiveness concerns, and the future of software development with AI assistants.
author: MIT Technology Review

title: The great AI hype correction of 2025
description: MIT Technology Review analyzes the shift from AI hype to realistic expectations in 2025. Discusses inflated claims meeting reality and what this means for AI development tools.
author: MIT Technology Review

title: JustHTML: A fascinating example of vibe engineering in action
description: Simon Willison analyzes JustHTML, a Python HTML5 parser built with coding agents. Details Emil Stenstr√∂m's sophisticated approach using multiple LLMs (Claude, Gemini), test-driven development with 9,200+ html5lib-tests, and professional software engineering practices - demonstrating 'vibe engineering' over 'vibe coding'.
author: Simon Willison
